V DZ več kot 7000 podpisov za enako plačilo malice vseh v komunali
04 Nov 2019, 11:45 by STA

Sindikat komunale in zbornica komunalnega gospodarstva sta v DZ vložila več kot 7000 podpisov za spremembo zakona, ki ureja višino regresa za prehrano med delom. Cilj je izenačitev zneska za malico za delavce v javnih in zasebnih komunalnih podjetjih, saj prvi letno prejmejo okoli 340 evrov regresa za prehrano manj, opozarjata sindikat in zbornica.



“Tudi direktorji komunalnih podjetij ugotavljajo, da delavci, ki nimajo zadostne prehrane, ne morejo dovolj učinkovito opravljati svojega dela," pravi direktor zbornice komunalnega gospodarstva Sebastijan Zupanc. Foto: pixabay.com

LJUBLJANA > "Gre za to, da so delavci v komunali upravičeni do različne višine povračila stroškov prehrane glede na to, kakšna je lastniška struktura delodajalca," je ob današnji predaji podpisov za spremembo zakona v Ljubljani opozorila predsednica sindikata komunale, varovanja in poslovanja z nepremičninami Slovenije Majda Marolt.
Kot je dodal direktor zbornice komunalnega gospodarstva pri Gospodarski zbornici Slovenije (GZS) Sebastijan Zupanc, gre za skoraj 10.000 delavcev v komunalni dejavnosti, ki so oškodovani za 340 evrov letno, kar je skoraj 30 evrov na mesec. "To v družinskem proračunu ob nizkih plačah, kot so v komunalnih dejavnostih, lahko veliko pomeni," je poudaril.
Delavec v komunalnem podjetju v državni ali občinski lasti je po pojasnilih Maroltove dnevno upravičen do nekaj več kot štirih evrov za malico, medtem ko je delavec v podjetju v zasebni lasti upravičen do 6,12 evra za malico dnevno.
Tako Maroltova kot Zupanc sta izpostavila, da gre za fizično intenzivna dela, ob čemer je Zupanc poudaril, da jih delavec preprosto ne more opravljati na žemljico in jogurt. "Dejstvo je, da tudi direktorji komunalnih podjetij ugotavljajo, da delavci, ki nimajo zadostne prehrane, ne morejo dovolj učinkovito opravljati svojega dela," je dodal.
Zakon o višini povračil stroškov v zvezi z delom in nekaterih drugih prejemkov, ki ureja višino nekaterih povračil v zvezi z delom, je v veljavi od leta 1997, z uveljavitvijo zakona za uravnoteženje javnih financ pa je zakon prenehal veljati za vse subjekte, razen za tiste, ki so v večinski lasti lokalnih skupnosti oziroma države.
"Mi smo se potrudili in prek Zveze svobodnih sindikatov Slovenije zadevo obravnavali v državnem svetu ter na ekonomsko-socialnem svetu, kjer so bili sprejeti sklepi za odpravo te krivice, a se ni zgodilo nič," je bila kritična Maroltova. Zdaj bodo imeli poslanci možnost, da to krivico odpravijo, je dodala.
"Mogoče malo nenavadno, da delodajalci in sindikati stopimo skupaj in zberemo podpise za odpravo anomalije, ki je prisotna že toliko let," je menil Zupanc, ki se mu odprava zdi neizbežna. Tudi on je pojasnil, da so zakonodajo skušali spremeniti že z več pobudami.
"Zakon je bil leta 2017 že v parlamentarni proceduri, nato pa iz nam neznanih razlogov umaknjen iz dnevnega reda. V medresorskem usklajevanju so ugotovili, da bodo zadevo reševali drugače, zdaj pa smo bili s sindikati v položaju, ko nam ni preostalo drugega, kot da začnemo zbirati podpise za odpravo te krivice," je ponovil.
DZ bo moral zdaj v 15 dneh zadevo obravnavati, potem gre v odločanje, je pojasnil Zupanc in sklenil, da bodo poskušali tematiko predstaviti tudi poslancem, da bodo lahko laže odločali o nadaljnjih postopkih.

There are more than 7000 signatures in the National Assembly for the equal payment of a small amount to everyone in the utility
04 Nov 2019, 11:45 by STA

The Union of Communal Services and the Chamber of Communal Economy have filed more than 7,000 signatures in the National Assembly to amend the law regulating the amount of recourse for eating while working. The goal is to equalize the amount of lunch for workers in public and private utilities, as the former receive about $ 340 less in annual food allowance, the union and the chamber warn.



"Even the directors of the utility companies find that workers who lack adequate nutrition cannot perform their work effectively enough," says Sebastijan Zupanc, director of the Utilities Chamber. Photo: pixabay.com

LJUBLJANA> "The point is that utility workers are entitled to different levels of reimbursement for food costs depending on the employer's ownership structure," the president of the union of the utility, security and real estate business warned today when submitting signatures to change the law in Ljubljana. Slovenia Majda Marolt.
According to Sebastijan Zupanc, director of the Chamber of Communal Services at the Chamber of Commerce and Industry of Slovenia (GZS), there are almost 10,000 workers in the utility sector who are injured for 340 euros a year, which is almost 30 euros a month. "This can mean a lot in the family budget at low salaries, such as in utilities," he stressed.
According to Marolt, a worker in a state-owned or municipal-owned utility company is entitled to just over four euros a day for lunch, while a worker in a privately owned company is entitled to $ 6.12 a day for lunch.
Both Marolt and Zupanc stressed that these were physically intense work, with Zupanc stressing that the worker simply could not do them on a bun and yogurt. "The fact is that the directors of the utility companies also find that workers who do not have sufficient nutrition cannot perform their work effectively enough," he added.
The Labor Reimbursement and Some Other Remuneration Act, which regulates the amount of certain labor reimbursements, has been in force since 1997, and with the enactment of the Public Finance Balance Act, the Act ceased to apply to all entities except those which are majority owned by local communities or the state.
"We did our best and through the Union of Free Trade Unions of Slovenia dealt with the matter in the national council and in the economic and social council, where decisions were taken to remedy this injustice, but nothing happened," Marolt said. Members will now have the opportunity to remedy this injustice, she added.
"It may be a little unusual for employers and trade unions to come together and collect signatures for the elimination of the anomaly that has been present for so many years," said Zupanc, who finds it inevitable. He also explained that several initiatives had been sought to change the legislation.
"The law was already in parliamentary procedure in 2017 and then withdrawn from the agenda for unknown reasons. In the inter-ministerial coordination, it was determined that the matter would be resolved differently, but now we were in a position with the unions when we had nothing left but to to start collecting signatures to remedy this injustice, "he reiterated.
The parliament will now have to consider the matter within 15 days, then it will be decided, Zupanc explained, and decided that they would try to present the topic to the deputies too, so that they would be able to decide on further procedures.
